intro: Tofieldia coccinea var. gracilis, commonly known as the redflower false lily, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the family Xanthorrhoeaceae and is characterized by its slender, grass-like foliage. The plant produces showy, red-orange flowers that bloom in late summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands or along stream banks. Its botanical features make it a valuable addition to native plant gardens and ecological restoration projects.
